channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Aid Agencies Fault U.N. Security Council on Syria Conflict
item.description: In a scathing report, a coalition of aid agencies said the council had failed to enforce its own resolutions on the delivery of humanitarian relief.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: U.S. Consulate Attack Was Foiled, Panel Says
item.description: A man from Pakistan who was a permanent resident of Canada told an undercover officer that he planned to bomb the United States Consulate or the financial district in Toronto, an immigration panel revealed on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Doctors’ Group Blames Government for Most Attacks on Medical Workers
item.description: More than 600 medical workers have been killed in Syria’s civil war in deliberate and indiscriminate attacks, most of them by government forces, an international rights group announced Wednesday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Mayoral Candidate Kidnapped and Killed, Prosecutors Say
item.description: A 42-year-old woman running for mayor in a southwestern state has been kidnapped and decapitated, state prosecutors said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Leader of Dissident Group Retains Her Post After Challenge
item.description: Cuba’s most high-profile opposition group, the Ladies in White, voted Wednesday to keep their leader, Berta Soler, in a referendum prompted by complaints that she was autocratic and should resign.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Megyer Journal: For Rent: A Hungarian Village, and a Mayoral Title
item.description: Megyer, with a population of 18, is leasing the right to be its deputy mayor, take over seven refurbished cottages and temporarily rename its streets.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Aron Ignacz, the only child in Megyer; Gusztav Egly, the village caretaker, preparing coffee for guests; the honeymoon suite; and the mayor, Kristof Pajer.

item.title: A Rift Imperils Authorization to Combat ISIS
item.description: President Obama’s request for authorization to fight the Islamic State is criticized by Republicans who say it does too little and by Democrats who say it does too much.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry sought Congress’s backing.

item.title: Frei Otto, Architect, Dies at 89; the Soap Bubble Was an Inspiration
item.description: A lack of construction materials after World War II forced Mr. Otto to innovate; he created dazzling tensile structures while minimizing the use of material.
item.dc:creator: FRED A. BERNSTEIN
item.media:description: Frei Otto, in an undated photo, will be awarded the Pritzker Prize.

item.title: Pritzker Prize for Frei Otto, German Architect, Is Announced After His Death
item.description: Mr. Otto was recognized for his airy tentlike structures and other inventive feats of engineering.
item.dc:creator: ROBIN POGREBIN
item.media:description: Mr. Otto's stadium roof canopies for the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich were widely admired for their lightness and strength.

item.title: Citing Fear of Neo-Nazi Group, a German Mayor Quits
item.description: Markus Nierth, 46, the mayor of Tröglitz, stepped down after the authorities declined to block a far-right demonstration outside his home.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Jan Woitas/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Markus Nierth speaking with journalists after he resigned as mayor of Tröglitz over fears about an anti-immigration march.

item.title: China’s Tensions With Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife
item.description: A comment by the Tibetan spiritual leader that he might not reincarnate has run afoul of the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama on Wednesday visited the Palpung Sherabling Monastery in northern India.

item.title: Family Denies Palestinian Killed by ISIS Was Spy
item.description: Mohamed Musallam was seen in a video released Tuesday by the Islamic State. Before he was shot in the head by a boy, he admitted under obvious duress that he was “an agent for the Israeli Mossad.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: The parents of Mohamed Musallam in East Jerusalem on Tuesday after a video released by the Islamic State purportedly showed him being killed.

item.title: Western Relations Frosty, Russia Warms to North Korea
item.description: On Wednesday, the Russian Foreign Ministry announced an agreement to designate 2015 as a “Year of Friendship” with North Korea.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un is to visit Russia in May, his first trip abroad as North Korean leader.

item.title: Liberian Leader Concedes Errors in Response to Ebola
item.description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf acknowledged on Wednesday that she had made a mistake in ordering a tough security crackdown at the height of the Ebola crisis last year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iraqi Army Cements Hold on Tikrit, but Islamic State Sends a Message
item.description: Militant fighters of the Islamic State set off 21 car bombs in the city of Ramadi but lost ground to an Iraqi government offensive in Tikrit, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Militiamen during an operation on Wednesday to take control of Tikrit, Iraq, from the Islamic State.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Tensions With Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife
item.description: A comment by the Tibetan spiritual leader that he might not reincarnate has run afoul of the Communist Party, which said he must, and that the party was the proper guardian of his succession.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A Tibetan at a refugee camp in Lalitpur, Nepal, with a portrait of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader.

item.title: Open Source: Republicans’ Iran Letter Ignites Fierce ‘#47Traitors’ Debate Online
item.description: The online political conversation in the United States continues to be dominated by a bitter debate over an open letter to the leaders of Iran.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Official Raises Doubts on Confession in Nemtsov Case
item.description: A member of the Kremlin’s advisory council on human rights said three of the suspects arrested after the death of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov had suffered injuries in captivity.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Zaur Dadayev, whom the Russian authorities say is the main suspect in the shooting death of Boris Y. Nemtsov, was escorted by the police from a courtroom in Moscow last week.

item.title: News Analysis: Obama Hands Venezuelan Leader a Cause to Stir Support
item.description: Washington’s hope that freezing assets of Venezuelan officials would focus attention on deteriorating conditions may have given President Nicolás Maduro momentum to crack down on his opposition.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Miraflores Palace, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela. The United States has formally declared his country an “extraordinary threat.’’

item.title: Plan to Verify Delhi Pollution Data Raises Suspicions
item.description: Some analysts accused the government of trying to hide data that shows the city’s air to be the world’s most toxic.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: A thick blanket of smoke at a garbage dump in New Delhi. The government says it will authenticate pollution levels before releasing the information to the public, a plan that critics say will deprive residents of the opportunity to protect themselves against bad air.
